00062 enum VSJNIMemoryModel
00063 {
00064   JAVA_STANDARD_HEAP = 0,
00065   JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS = 1,
00066   JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION = 2,
00067   NATIVE_BUFFERS = 3,
00068   NATIVE_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION = 4,
00069 };
00070 
00071 static enum VSJNIMemoryModel sVSJNI_IsMirroringNativeMemoryInJVM =
00072 #ifdef VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00073     JAVA_STANDARD_HEAP;
00074 #else
00075 NATIVE_BUFFERS;
00076 #endif

00086 JNIMemoryManager::malloc(size_t requested_size)

00091 void *
00092 JNIMemoryManager::malloc(void* obj, size_t requested_size)
00093 {
00094   void * retval = VSJNI_malloc(static_cast<jobject> (obj), requested_size);
00095   return retval;
00096 }

00108 static JavaVM* sCachedJVM = 0;
00109 #ifdef VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00110 static JNIEnv*
00111 VSJNI_getEnv();
00112 static jclass sByteBufferReferenceClass = 0;
00113 static jmethodID sByteBufferAllocateDirectMethod = 0;
00114 static jclass sJNIMemoryAllocatorClass = 0;
00115 static jmethodID sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod = 0;
00116 static jmethodID sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod = 0;
00117 #endif // VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00118 /*
00119  * This method is called by the JNIHelper when it loads up and
00120  * BEFORE it tries to allocate memory.
00121  *
00122  * WARNING: DO NOT CALL JNIHELPER METHODS HERE DIRECTLY; THEY
00123  * RELY ON CREATING A JNIHELPER OBJECT WHICH USES NEW!
00124  */
00125 void
00126 VSJNI_MemoryManagerInit(JavaVM* aJVM)
00127 {
00128   sCachedJVM = aJVM;
00129 
00130 #ifdef VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00131 
00134   try
00135   {
00136     // Now, let's cache the commonly used classes.
00137     JNIEnv *env = VSJNI_getEnv();
00138     if (!env)
00139       throw std::runtime_error("could not find environment");
00140 
00141     jclass cls = env->FindClass("java/nio/ByteBuffer");
00142     if (!cls)
00143       throw std::runtime_error("could not find java.nio.ByteBuffer class");
00144 
00145     sByteBufferReferenceClass = (jclass) env->NewWeakGlobalRef(cls);
00146     if (!sByteBufferReferenceClass)
00147       throw std::runtime_error("could not get weak reference for class");
00148 
00149     sByteBufferAllocateDirectMethod = env->GetStaticMethodID(cls,
00150         "allocateDirect", "(I)Ljava/nio/ByteBuffer;");
00151     if (!sByteBufferAllocateDirectMethod)
00152       throw std::runtime_error(
00153           "could not find allocateDirect(int) method in java.nio.ByteBuffer");
00154     env->DeleteLocalRef(cls);
00155     if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00156       throw std::runtime_error("got exception in jni");
00157 
00158     cls = env->FindClass("com/xuggle/ferry/JNIMemoryAllocator");
00159     if (!cls)
00160       throw std::runtime_error(
00161           "could not find com.xuggle.ferry.JNIMemoryAllocatorclass");
00162 
00163     sJNIMemoryAllocatorClass = (jclass) env->NewWeakGlobalRef(cls);
00164     if (!sJNIMemoryAllocatorClass)
00165       throw std::runtime_error("could not get weak reference for class");
00166 
00167     sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod = env->GetMethodID(cls, "malloc", "(I)[B");
00168     if (!sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod)
00169       throw std::runtime_error(
00170           "could not find malloc(int) method in com.xuggle.ferry.JNIMemoryAllocator");
00171     sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod = env->GetMethodID(cls, "free", "([B)V");
00172     if (!sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod)
00173       throw std::runtime_error(
00174           "could not find free(byte[]) method in com.xuggle.ferry.JNIMemoryAllocator");
00175   }
00176   catch (std::exception e)
00177   {
00178     // DON'T HAVE JAVA do memory management.
00179     sCachedJVM = 0;
00180 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00181     fprintf(stderr,
00182         "got exception initializing jvm; using stdlib for memory allocation\n");
00183 #endif
00184   }
00185 #else
00186 #endif // VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANGEMENT
00187 }
00188 
00189 #ifdef VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00190 static JNIEnv*
00191 VSJNI_getEnv()
00192 {
00193   JNIEnv * env = 0;
00194   if (sCachedJVM)
00195   {
00196     jint retval = sCachedJVM->GetEnv((void**) (void*) &env, JNI_VERSION_1_2);
00197     if (retval == JNI_EDETACHED)
00198       throw std::runtime_error("not attached to JVM");
00199 
00200     if (retval == JNI_EVERSION)
00201       throw std::runtime_error("Java v1.2 not supported");
00202 
00203   }
00204   return env;
00205 }
00206 
00207 struct VSJNI_AllocationHeader
00208 {
00214   jobject mRef;
00219   jobject mAllocator;
00223   enum VSJNIMemoryModel mModel;
00224 };
00225 
00226 static void *
00227 VS_JNI_malloc_native(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj, size_t requested_size,
00228     bool notifyJavaHeap)
00229 {
00230   void *retval = 0;
00231   void *buffer = 0;
00232 
00233   if (notifyJavaHeap && env){
00234     jbyteArray bytearray= 0;
00235     if (obj)
00236     {
00237       // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00238       bytearray = static_cast<jbyteArray> (env->CallObjectMethod(obj,
00239           sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod, requested_size
00240               + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY));
00241     }
00242     else
00243     {
00244       // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00245       bytearray = env->NewByteArray(requested_size
00246           + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY);
00247     }
00248     if (!bytearray)
00249       throw std::bad_alloc();
00250     if (obj) {
00251       // Tell the allocator we're done
00252       // We're relying on the fact that the WeakReference passed in
00253       // is always outlived
00254       // by the allocator object (knock on wood)
00255       env->CallVoidMethod(obj,
00256           sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod, bytearray);
00257       if (env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00258         env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00259         throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00260       }
00261     }
00262     env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00263     if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00264       throw std::bad_alloc();
00265   }
00266 
00267   // We're not in a JVM, so use malloc/free instead
00268   buffer = malloc((int) requested_size + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader)
00269       + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY);
00270   VSJNI_AllocationHeader *header = (VSJNI_AllocationHeader*) buffer;
00271   if (!header)
00272     throw std::bad_alloc();
00273   // initialize the header to 0; that way later on delete we can tell
00274   // if this was JVMed or Malloced.
00275   memset(header, 0, sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00276   header->mModel = NATIVE_BUFFERS;
00277 
00278   retval = (void*) ((char*) header + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00279   return retval;
00280 }
00281 
00282 static void *
00283 VS_JNI_malloc_javaDirectBufferBacked(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj,
00284     size_t requested_size,
00285     bool notifyJavaHeap)
00286 {
00287   void *retval = 0;
00288   void *buffer = 0;
00289   // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00290   jlong size = requested_size + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader)
00291       + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY;
00292 
00293   if (env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00294     throw std::bad_alloc();
00295   }
00296   
00297   // First, let's exert some pressure on the non-direct java heap
00298   if (notifyJavaHeap){
00299     jbyteArray bytearray= 0;
00300     if (obj)
00301     {
00302       // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00303       bytearray = static_cast<jbyteArray> (env->CallObjectMethod(obj,
00304           sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod, requested_size
00305               + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY));
00306     }
00307     else
00308     {
00309       // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00310       bytearray = env->NewByteArray(requested_size
00311           + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY);
00312     }
00313     if (!bytearray)
00314       throw std::bad_alloc();
00315     if (obj) {
00316       // Tell the allocator we're done
00317       // We're relying on the fact that the WeakReference passed in
00318       // is always outlived
00319       // by the allocator object (knock on wood)
00320       env->CallVoidMethod(obj,
00321           sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod, bytearray);
00322       if (env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00323         env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00324         throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00325       }
00326     }
00327     env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00328     if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00329       throw std::bad_alloc();
00330   }
00331   jclass cls = static_cast<jclass>(env->NewLocalRef(sByteBufferReferenceClass));
00332   if (!cls)
00333   {
00334     throw std::bad_alloc();
00335   }
00336   jobject bytearray = env->CallStaticObjectMethod(sByteBufferReferenceClass,
00337       sByteBufferAllocateDirectMethod, (jint)size);
00338   env->DeleteLocalRef(cls);
00339   // if JVM didn't like that, return bad_alloc(); when we return all the way back to
00340   // JVM the Exception in Java will still exist; even if someone else catches
00341   // std::bad_alloc()
00342   if (!bytearray || env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00343     throw std::bad_alloc();
00344   }
00345 
00346   jlong availableCapacity = env->GetDirectBufferCapacity(bytearray);
00347   if (env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00348     throw std::bad_alloc();
00349   }
00350   if (availableCapacity < size) {
00351     throw std::bad_alloc();
00352   }
00353 
00354   buffer = env->GetDirectBufferAddress(bytearray);
00355   if (!buffer || env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00356     throw std::bad_alloc();
00357   }
00358 
00359   // We're going to take up the first few (usually 4 on 32bit
00360   // and 8 on 64 bit machines)
00361   // bytes of this for our header, so be aware if you use this 
00362   // for really small objects
00363   // that the overhead is QUITE high.
00364   VSJNI_AllocationHeader* header = (VSJNI_AllocationHeader*) buffer;
00365   memset(header, 0, sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00366 
00367   // And tell the JVM that it can't cleanup the bytearray yet; we've got
00368   // things to do and places to go.
00369   header->mRef = static_cast<jobject> (env->NewGlobalRef(bytearray));
00370   if (!header->mRef || env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00371     throw std::bad_alloc();
00372   }
00373   header->mModel = JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS;
00374 
00375   // But be nice and delete the local ref we had since we now have a
00376   // stronger reference.
00377   env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00378   if (env->ExceptionCheck()) {
00379     env->DeleteLocalRef(header->mRef);
00380     throw std::bad_alloc();
00381   }
00382   // Finally, return the buffer, but skip past our header
00383   retval = (void*) ((char*) buffer + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00384   return retval;
00385 }
00386 
00387 static void *
00388 VS_JNI_malloc_javaByteBacked(JNIEnv* env, jobject obj, size_t requested_size)
00389 {
00390   void* retval = 0;
00391   void* buffer = 0;
00392   // make sure we don't already have a pending exception
00393   if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00394     throw std::bad_alloc();
00395 
00396   jbyteArray bytearray = 0;
00397   if (obj)
00398   {
00399     // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00400     bytearray = static_cast<jbyteArray> (env->CallObjectMethod(obj,
00401         sJNIMemoryAllocatorMallocMethod, requested_size
00402             + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY));
00403   }
00404   else
00405   {
00406     // We allocate a byte array for the actual memory
00407     bytearray = env->NewByteArray(requested_size
00408         + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader) + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY);
00409   }
00410 
00411   // if JVM didn't like that, return bad_alloc(); when we 
00412   // return all the way back to
00413   // JVM the Exception in Java will still exist; even if someone else catches
00414   // std::bad_alloc()
00415   if (!bytearray)
00416     throw std::bad_alloc();
00417   if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00418     throw std::bad_alloc();
00419 
00420   // Now this is the actual memory pointed to by the java byte array
00421   // I use a void* buffer here so I can peak more easily in a debugger
00422   buffer = (void*) (env->GetByteArrayElements(bytearray, 0));
00423   if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00424     throw std::bad_alloc();
00425 
00426   // Technically this should never occur (i.e. if buffer is null
00427   // then a Java exception should have occurred).  still, we'll
00428   // be doubly safe for fun
00429   if (!buffer)
00430     throw std::bad_alloc();
00431 
00432   VSJNI_AllocationHeader* header = (VSJNI_AllocationHeader*) buffer;
00433   memset(header, 0, sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00434 
00435   // And tell the JVM that it can't cleanup the bytearray yet; we've got
00436   // things to do and places to go.
00437   header->mRef = env->NewGlobalRef(bytearray);
00438   if (!header->mRef)
00439     throw std::bad_alloc();
00440   header->mAllocator = 0;
00441   if (obj)
00442   {
00443     header->mAllocator = env->NewGlobalRef(obj);
00444     if (!header->mAllocator)
00445       throw std::bad_alloc();
00446   }
00447   header->mModel = JAVA_STANDARD_HEAP;
00448 
00449   // But be nice and delete the local ref we had since we now have a
00450   // stronger reference.
00451   env->DeleteLocalRef(bytearray);
00452   if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00453     throw std::bad_alloc();
00454 
00455   // Finally, return the buffer, but skip past our header
00456   retval = (void*) ((char*) buffer + sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00457   return retval;
00458 }
00459 
00460 static void *
00461 VSJNI_malloc(jobject obj, size_t requested_size)
00462 {
00463   try
00464   {
00465     void* retval = 0;
00466     JNIEnv* env = 0;
00467 
00468     if ((int) requested_size > INT_MAX - VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY)
00469       // we need 16 byte clearance; and only support up to 4GBs.  Sorry folks, if
00470       // you need more than 4GB of contiguous memory, it's not us.
00471       return 0;
00472 
00473     (void) obj;
00474     env = VSJNI_getEnv();
00475     enum VSJNIMemoryModel model = sVSJNI_IsMirroringNativeMemoryInJVM;
00476     if (!env)
00477       model = NATIVE_BUFFERS;
00478     switch (model)
00479     {
00480       case JAVA_STANDARD_HEAP:
00481         retval = VS_JNI_malloc_javaByteBacked(env, obj, requested_size);
00482         break;
00483       case JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS:
00484         retval = VS_JNI_malloc_javaDirectBufferBacked(env, obj, requested_size,
00485             false);
00486         break;
00487       case JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION:
00488         retval = VS_JNI_malloc_javaDirectBufferBacked(env, obj, requested_size,
00489             true);
00490         break;
00491       case NATIVE_BUFFERS:
00492         retval = VS_JNI_malloc_native(env, obj, requested_size, false);
00493         break;
00494       case NATIVE_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION:
00495         retval = VS_JNI_malloc_native(env, obj, requested_size, true);
00496         break;
00497       default:
00498         throw std::bad_alloc();
00499         break;
00500     }
00501 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00502     fprintf (stderr, "alloc: returned %p(%lld) size (%ld); model: %d\n",
00503         retval,
00504         (long long) retval,
00505         (long)requested_size,
00506         model);
00507 #endif
00508     // Now, align on VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY byte boundary;
00509     // on Posix system we could have used memalign for the malloc,
00510     // but that doesn't work
00511     // for Java allocations, so we do this hack for everyone.
00512     return VSJNI_alignMemory(retval);
00513   }
00514   catch (std::bad_alloc & e)
00515   {
00516 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00517     fprintf (stderr, "alloc: bad_alloc of size %ld\n",
00518         (long)requested_size);
00519 #endif
00520     return 0;
00521   }
00522 }
00523 
00531 static void
00532 VSJNI_free(void * mem)
00533 {
00534   void *buffer = 0;
00535   if (mem)
00536   {
00537     // realign back to original boundary
00538     mem = VSJNI_unalignMemory(mem);
00539 
00540     // Find the actual start of the memory
00541     buffer = (void*) ((char*) mem - sizeof(VSJNI_AllocationHeader));
00542 
00543     // Get our header
00544     VSJNI_AllocationHeader *header = (VSJNI_AllocationHeader*) buffer;
00545     enum VSJNIMemoryModel model = header->mModel;
00546     JNIEnv* env = VSJNI_getEnv();
00547     switch(model)
00548     {
00549       case JAVA_STANDARD_HEAP:
00550       {
00551         if (!env)
00552           // just leak; doesn't make any sense that we're here.
00553           return;
00554         if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00555           throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00556 
00557         if (header->mAllocator)
00558         {
00559           // Tell the allocator we're done
00560           // We're relying on the fact that the WeakReference passed in
00561           // is always outlived
00562           // by the allocator object (knock on wood)
00563           env->CallVoidMethod(header->mAllocator,
00564               sJNIMemoryAllocatorFreeMethod, header->mRef);
00565           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00566             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00567           env->DeleteGlobalRef(header->mAllocator);
00568           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00569             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00570         }
00571 
00572         // Get a local copy so that when we delete the global
00573         // ref, the gc thread won't free the underlying memory
00574         if (header->mRef)
00575         {
00576           jbyteArray array = static_cast<jbyteArray> (env->NewLocalRef(
00577               header->mRef));
00578           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00579             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00580           if (!array)
00581             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00582 
00583           // delete the global ref, so that when we return the
00584           // jvm can gc
00585           env->DeleteGlobalRef(header->mRef);
00586           header->mRef = 0;
00587           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00588             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00589 
00590           // Tell the JVM to release the elements of raw memory
00591           env->ReleaseByteArrayElements(array, (jbyte*) buffer, JNI_ABORT);
00592           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00593             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00594 
00595           // and we should be careful to delete our local ref because
00596           // we don't know how deep we are in native calls, or when
00597           // we'll actually return to the jvm
00598           env->DeleteLocalRef(array);
00599           if (env->ExceptionCheck())
00600             throw std::runtime_error("got java exception");
00601         }
00602       }
00603         break;
00604       case JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS:
00606       case JAVA_DIRECT_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION:
00607       {
00608         if (!env)
00609           return;
00610         // delete the global ref, so that when we return the
00611         // jvm can gc
00612         jobject ref = header->mRef;
00613         header->mRef = 0;
00614         if (ref != 0)
00615           env->DeleteGlobalRef(ref);
00616       }
00617         break;
00618       case NATIVE_BUFFERS:
00620       case NATIVE_BUFFERS_WITH_STANDARD_HEAP_NOTIFICATION:
00621       {
00622         free(buffer);
00623       }
00624         break;
00625       default:
00626         fprintf(stderr, "ERROR: Should never get here\n");
00628         break;
00629     }
00630 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00631     printf("free: orig %p (%lld) adjusted %p (%lld); model %d\n",
00632         mem,
00633         (long long) mem,
00634         buffer,
00635         (long long)buffer,
00636         model);
00637 #endif
00638   }
00639 }
00640 
00641 #else
00642 static void *VSJNI_malloc(jobject, size_t requested_size)
00643 {
00644   void* retval = 0;
00645 
00646   if (
00647       (sizeof(size_t) == 4 && (int)requested_size > INT_MAX - VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY) ||
00648       ((long long)requested_size > LLONG_MAX - VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY))
00649   // we need 16 byte clearance; ok, for 64-bit machines if you're
00650   // asking for 9-Tera-Whatevers of memory, you'll fail anyway,
00651   // but we try to be complete.
00652   return 0;
00653   retval = malloc(requested_size + VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY);
00654   if (!retval)
00655   return 0;
00656 
00657   return VSJNI_alignMemory(retval);
00658 }
00659 static void
00660 VSJNI_free(void * mem)
00661 {
00662   // realign back to original boundary
00663   if (mem)
00664   {
00665     mem = VSJNI_unalignMemory(mem);
00666     free(mem);
00667   }
00668 }
00669 #endif // USE_JVM_FOR_MEM_MANAGEMENT
00670 static void*
00671 VSJNI_alignMemory(void* aInput)
00672 {
00673   void* retval = aInput;
00674   retval = aInput;
00675   int alignDiff = ((-(long) retval - 1) & (VSJNI_ALIGNMENT_BOUNDARY - 1)) + 1;
00676   retval = (char*) retval + alignDiff;
00677   ((char*) retval)[-1] = (char) alignDiff;
00678 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00679   printf ("align: orig(%p:%lld) new(%p:%lld) align(%d)\n",
00680       aInput, (long long)aInput,
00681       retval, (long long) retval,
00682       alignDiff);
00683 #endif
00684 
00685   return retval;
00686 }
00687 
00694 static void*
00695 VSJNI_unalignMemory(void *aInput)
00696 {
00697   int alignDiff = ((char*) aInput)[-1];
00698   void * retval = (void*) (((char*) aInput) - alignDiff);
00699 #ifdef VSJNI_MEMMANAGER_DEBUG
00700   printf ("unalign: orig(%p:%lld) new(%p:%lld) align(%d)\n",
00701       aInput, (long long)aInput,
00702       retval, (long long) retval,
00703       alignDiff);
00704 #endif
00705   return retval;
00706 }
00707 
00714 #ifdef VSJNI_OVERRIDE_CPP_NEW_AND_DELETE
00715 VS_API_FERRY void *
00716 operator new (size_t requested_size)
00717 {
00718   return VSJNI_malloc(0, requested_size);
00719 }
00720 
00721 VS_API_FERRY void
00722 operator delete (void *mem)
00723 {
00724   VSJNI_free(mem);
00725 }
00726 #endif // VSJNI_OVERRIDE_CPP_NEW_AND_DELETE
00727 
00730 extern "C"
00731 {
00732 JNIEXPORT void JNICALL
00733 Java_com_xuggle_ferry_JNIMemoryAllocator_setAllocator(JNIEnv *, jclass,
00734     jlong aNativeObj, jobject aMemMgr)
00735 {
00736   // assume that the native object is a RefCounted
00737   com::xuggle::ferry::RefCounted *obj =
00738       *(com::xuggle::ferry::RefCounted**) &aNativeObj;
00739   obj->setJavaAllocator(aMemMgr);
00740 }
00741 
00742 JNIEXPORT jobject JNICALL
00743 Java_com_xuggle_ferry_JNIMemoryAllocator_getAllocator(JNIEnv *env, jclass,
00744     jlong aNativeObj)
00745 {
00746   // assume that the native object is a RefCounted
00747   com::xuggle::ferry::RefCounted *obj =
00748       *(com::xuggle::ferry::RefCounted**) &aNativeObj;
00749   jobject result = (jobject) obj->getJavaAllocator();
00750   if (result)
00751     result = env->NewLocalRef(result);
00752   return result;
00753 }
00754 
00755 JNIEXPORT jint JNICALL
00756 Java_com_xuggle_ferry_FerryJNI_getMemoryModel(JNIEnv *, jclass)
00757 {
00758   return (jint) sVSJNI_IsMirroringNativeMemoryInJVM;
00759 }
00760 
00761 JNIEXPORT void JNICALL
00762 Java_com_xuggle_ferry_FerryJNI_setMemoryModel(JNIEnv *, jclass, jint value)
00763 {
00764 #ifdef VSJNI_USE_JVM_FOR_MEMMANAGEMENT
00765   sVSJNI_IsMirroringNativeMemoryInJVM = (enum VSJNIMemoryModel) value;
00766 #endif
00767 }

00769 }
